Fixed Official Imagen Python Snippet | Generated by AI

Home 2025.10

You‚Äôve basically implemented the correct logic, but the get‚Äëunstuck instructions are slightly off. Here‚Äôs a cleaned‚Äëup version adapted from the official example in the docs:

from google import genai
from google.genai import types
from PIL import Image
from io import BytesIO

# ‚Üê Set your API key or use the environment variable GOOGLE_API_KEY / GEMINI_API_KEY
client = genai.Client(api_key="YOUR_API_KEY")

response = client.models.generate_images(
    model="imagen-4.0-generate-preview-06-06",
    prompt="A dog reading a newspaper",
    config=types.GenerateImagesConfig(
        number_of_images=1,
        # image_size="2K",  # optional for 2K resolution; requires newer fast-preview library
        aspect_ratio="1:1",
        safety_filter_level="BLOCK_MEDIUM_AND_ABOVE",
        person_generation="ALLOW_ADULT",
    )
)

for i, generated in enumerate(response.generated_images):
    raw = generated.image.image_bytes
    pil = Image.open(BytesIO(raw))  # Convert raw bytes into a PIL image
    pil.save(f"output-image-{i+1}.png")
    print(f"Saved image {i+1}, {len(raw):,} bytes")

While Google‚Äôs Python snippet also used image_size="2K" for its 4‚Äëpreview model, be aware that:

  • You must be running google-genai v1.28 or newer to support image_size on Imagen 4 models;
  • Otherwise omit that field (the default is 1,024√ó1,024 at a fixed square pixel resolution) (GitHub).

üö© Common Pitfalls & Fixes

  1. Missing PIL installation If you installed google-genai but didn‚Äôt add Pillow, .image.save() calls may fail silently (or raise AttributeError). Make sure:

    pip install pillow

  2. No API key or wrong service selected If you call genai.Client() with no API key and without cloud credentials, the client fails at call-time with an authentication error (e.g., "401 UNAUTHENTICATED"). Either pass api_key="‚Ä¶" or set GOOGLE_API_KEY in your shell, for Gemini Developer API (GitHub).

  3. Library version mismatch Older versions of the library or legacy google.generativeai module don‚Äôt expose generate_images() and may still default to the deprecated generative-ai interface. Always ensure:

    pip install --upgrade google-genai

    The issue ‚Äúcannot open the output images‚Äù in older repos (deprecated-generative-ai-python) resulted from that mismatch, and usually threw UnidentifiedImageError or FileNotFoundError after writing broken bytes (GitHub).

  4. UnidentifiedImageError when opening with PIL If you see:

    PIL.UnidentifiedImageError: cannot identify image file <_io.BytesIO ‚Ä¶>

    that usually means the response buffer is corrupted or incomplete. Double-check that:

    • Your prompt wasn‚Äôt filtered (e.g. RAI blocking);
    • You aren‚Äôt base64‚Äëdecoding the bytes (the SDK already returns raw PNG/JPEG data);
    • Your file download isn‚Äôt cut short.

‚úÖ Why This Fix Works

  • The official snippet in Google‚Äôs docs on 2025‚Äë08‚Äë01 exactly uses:

    types.GenerateImagesConfig(image_size="2K")

    before saving via result.image.save(...) (Google Cloud).

  • But other guides using Imagen 3‚Äìmodels only specify number_of_images, aspect_ratio, and safety settings‚Äîwithout image_size‚Äîbecause Imagen¬†3 doesn‚Äôt support it (GitHub).

Following the flow above should get you unblocked. If you run into a specific error message (like HTTP 403, missing JSON key in response, etc.), feel free to paste that back and I‚Äôll help you troubleshoot the next step.
